channel.title: Christian Science Monitor | Top Stories
channel.description: Read the front page stories of csmonitor.com.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2003 The Christian Science Monitor. All rights reserved. This RSS file is offered to individuals and non-commercial organizations only. Newspapers, magazines, and other commercial websites wishing to use Monitor RSS files, please contact syndication@csmonitor.com.

item.title: The East-West stakes over Ukraine
item.description: Russian and Western leaders are sharply at odds over the country's election crisis.

item.title: Retailers glow with hope for a holiday boost
item.description: The job market is better and oil prices are down, improving the holiday shopping outlook.

item.title: In pockets of Fallujah, US troops still face harsh battles
item.description: Just four insurgents tied down a Marine company for hours in a nighttime battle.

item.title: How drug-approval woes crept up on FDA
item.description: Critics charge conflict of interest in a system where pharmaceutical giants fund the regulatory process.

item.title: Up next: network news at crossroads
item.description: Departure of two anchors comes as television networks face shifts in viewership.

item.title: Intelligence reform already in gear
item.description: Whether or not the reform bill becomes law, the CIA is facing a transformation unparalleled in three decades.

item.title: Shifting signs in North Korea
item.description: Kim Jong Il dials back his personality cult as protest activities pick up.

item.title: A river and region face a toxic past
item.description: The cleanup of the Fox River's contaminated sediments will likely prove one of largest ever in the US.

item.title: Why AIDS keeps spreading in Africa
item.description: A new UN report, marking Wednesday's World AIDS day, estimates that 5 million people this year got HIV.

item.title: In Chile, instant Web feedback creates the next day's paper
item.description: The system offers a direct barometer of public opinion, much like the TV rating system - but unique to print media.
